respondent.name: JAMES R. McDONOUGH, INTERIM SECRETARY, FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF CORRECTIONS.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in 04-1324, Day versus McDonough. Mr. Busby.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It was a computation error.  This is not a -- this is not a case where the State chose to waive the statute of limitations.  It miscalculated.  Isn't that the case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But we're not -- and we didn't take cert to decide if this claim was timely. We are on the assumption that it was untimely.  But -- and what are the consequences of the State's failing to raise that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- the whole basis was the number of days that they calculated, and the magistrate said, "Oh, they miscalculated.  There were more days involved."

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Suppose --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Suppose the magistrate judge had said, "I notice this error in accordance with Eleventh Circuit law, so I am going to suggest to 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 the State that they amend their answer."  The State certainly could -- under Rule 15, if the Federal rules apply, the State could have amended its answer and done just what the magistrate judge did.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Did it say "an obligation," or that the court "could"?  It didn't -- I didn't think it said the court "must."

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Where is -- I see -- you're referring to page 4(a) and --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes.  Which -- where is the sentence that says it -- that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought that that duty 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 is in connection with Rule 4.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So, the -- it's right that there's an obligation if it notices it in the first instance on its first review.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And suppose, under the review proceedings, that District Court is looking at it for the first time, without yet having required a response, and he sees a statute of limitation.  I assume there's an obligation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Sure.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I mean, if -- suppose it's an open-and-shut violation of the statute of 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 limitations, or barred by the statute of limitations - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- does District Court have discretion to refer to the State for a response?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Really?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No, my --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No, my --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- my hypothetical is that it is.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Because the other -- because the other side might make a mistake and not recognize it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Or the other side may say, "Although technically the statute of limitations applied here, taking all considerations into account we think that this prisoner acted with reasonable promptness, and perhaps the delay was somewhat attributable to the State."  Do you think that that's a proper consideration?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But you -- it could be argued that the Federal Government wants to move them along speedily, whether or not the State government wants to.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So, that would suggest that the State's voluntary waiver of a statute of limitations should not make any difference.  It's a Federal -- it's a Federal interest involved, not a State interest.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, we could --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- we could -- we could agree with you that there is isn't an obligation on 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 the Federal judge to raise it, but the question is, you know, the -- it could be a "must," it can be "may not," or it could be "may."

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And why shouldn't we treat this as a "may"?  The judge noticed the clerical error and called it to the party's attention by an order to show cause.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: We're past Rule 4, because an answer has been ordered.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So -- and it's only when the answer comes in that this issue is spotted.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There are very what standards? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes, "leave shall be freely given."

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, what would be the prejudice that could be claimed by the habeas petitioner?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Are you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Are you saying that the error is simply that it wasn't done via Rule 15?  What if we were to say that the same considerations apply when it's simply raised sua sponte by the -- by the -- by the District Court?  What would be your objection to that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you couldn't do this under Rule 4, because, as you, I think, recognized, that, just from the petition, from the habeas 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 petition, you couldn't tell.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There wasn't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, if you think it's -- if it's done under Rule 15, would the considerations necessarily be exactly the same in a habeas case as in an ordinary civil case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes, but the civil rules allow for amendment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There's 8(c), and there's 12(b), but there's also 15.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It seems the height of technicality to say that the judge could suggest, "Now, State, I will entertain a motion to amend the answer, under Rule 15," instead of saying, "I'm issuing an order to show cause why this action is not out of time."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why does -- proceeding under 15 does not do that; whereas, proceeding this way does?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Wink, wink?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, there is some value in that, I think, particularly where the State has expressly conceded timeliness.  I mean, the magistrate judge in this case, all that he had before him was the express concession from the State.  He never -- the State never said anything in the District Court, even after he issued his notice to the Petitioner to show cause why it wasn't untimely.  So, the magistrate judge, all he had before him was the State's position that it was timely.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Isn't that concern present in Granberry, as well?  And yet, the Court reached the opposite result there.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: One that requires the court to raise it sua sponte, even if it's not raised by the State.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: One that requires the court to raise it sua sponte, even if not raised by the State, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Your position is, it should be like any other civil case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You can raise it sua sponte, we've said, in exceptional circumstances.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I don't know what they are.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And if --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- they're not there --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- then the judge could say, "You know, I'm surprised that you haven't raised statute of limitations."

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And then the lawyer for the State says, "Oh, my goodness.  Quite right.  We'd like to amend." 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And we don't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- have to decide --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Must there be good reasons for the judge to say, quote, "I'm surprised that you haven't raised a statute of limitations defense"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Must there be good reason for that?  And, if not, aren't you asking us to waste our time?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why don't you do it the easier way and --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, what's your answer as to whether there is any limitation on the judge just suggesting, "By the way, you know, is there some reason why you haven't pleaded statute of limitations?"  Can a -- can a judge do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And what -- when would it be an abuse of discretion?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, it wouldn't --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- be an abuse of --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It wouldn't be an 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 abuse of discretion for him to suggest an amendment if he's got the opportunity to rule on the amendment later on.  And then presumably the ruling would be reviewed for abuse of discretion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I suppose it might be an abuse of discretion if you'd already had a hearing and took -- and decided that there was merit to the plaintiff's claim, and then decided, "Well, now I'm going to just throw it out on limitations," might be an abuse of discretion.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, then why doesn't that same standard apply to the decision of the Court to raise it sua sponte?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Were those --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- cases -- were those cases of a miscalculation on the part of the State? The judge's view was that the State had miscalculated under eleventh-amendment -- under Eleventh Circuit precedent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So, you'd say it would be okay if the State didn't expressly concede the statute of limitations point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's what I thought your

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- position was.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay.  So, this --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- a fallback position.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why, just out of curiosity -- I'm not familiar with the actual practice of a lot of civil cases, but when somebody -- let's say the defendant in an ordinary tort case forgets to put in 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 the statute of limitations, and the case is all tried and finished.  At the very end, he says, "Oh, my God." And now he goes in and asks to amend it under Rule Do judges normally say, "Fine"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Because it's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But here, nothing --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- happened.  Nothing happened.  There was --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The answer was put in, and then there were no further proceedings.  Nothing else went on in the court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It's quite different -- I don't know any judge that would allow a defendant, after the trial is over, to raise the statute of limitations. But, up front, it's a different situation. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. Mr. Kise.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You think the court "must."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, don't you think that's what this court thought?  And, if so, shouldn't we perhaps send it back to see whether, if the court knew that it had discretion, it would have done this?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes, but, Mr. Kise, the - 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 - Mr. Busby told us that the reference was in the following paragraph, and it is the sentence, "A Federal Court that sits in collateral review of a criminal judgment of a State Court has an obligation to enforce the Federal statute of limitations." That's the sentence that suggests that the Court of Appeals thought that there was an obligation, the District Court, to raise the statute of limitations on its own motion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What would you say -- assuming that we're beyond Rule 4, what would you say simply to a rule that said, "Yes, we recognize that there remains a discretion -- not an obligation, but a discretion -- on the part of the court to raise this." But, just as a -- as a general rule, judicial efficiency is better served by avoiding the use of discretion unless the State, in fact, raises the limitations issue, itself.  The courts have a lot of things to do, and they shouldn't be spending their time canvassing pleadings to see whether there might be an issue that the State missed; so that in the absence of some extraordinary circumstance, it would be an abuse of discretion to exercise it as the -- as the Circuit suggests it should have been exercised here.  What would you say to that position?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What, then, would be the significance here of the fact that the State conceded that there was no limitations problem?  In a case like that, wouldn't it be a good rule to avoid judicial inquiry?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, but it bears on the exercise of discretion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: That would be an abuse.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: District judges can't comment on the cases?  And -- they suddenly raise something, curious about something; and, lo and behold, it becomes the subject of an amendment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's a violation of -- I mean, what I'm driving at is, I don't really understand Rule 15 thoroughly, because I'm not a trial lawyer.  And why do we have to decide every matter? Why don't we let the District judge free to run his trial and just say, "Hey, we don't want to proliferate law.  It's complicated enough already.  Let's leave it to Rule 15, whatever that might be"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, but the other way means we're now going to have a new area of law.  The new area of law consists of habeas law involving what is the equivalent of an amendment suggested by the judge to bring up a statute.  That would be good, because West would then have five more pages, with a new keynote -- [Laughter.]

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- and there would be more for lawyers to look up.  Whereas, if you just say Rule 15, it's finished.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Would you say it's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- means it's "hardly ever"?  I mean, we do follow the principle of party presentation.  And judges are not supposed to be intruding issues on their own, they are supposed to follow the party's presentation.  So, would this be -- if it's not "never," would it be at least "hardly ever," that it's appropriate for a judge to interject an affirmative defense on his own motion?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What if Congress wanted to leave it to the State to waive the statute of limitations provision?  How could it have made that clear?  I mean, I would have thought that if they made it a statute of limitations provision instead of a jurisdictional provision -- I mean, they could have said, you know, "No jurisdiction if it's filed beyond a certain date, and we mean it."  But it put it as a statute of limitation, which normally is waivable. And I would think that that is an indication that Congress thought, "Really, if the State thinks that in this particular case we shouldn't hew to the technicality of the statute of limitation, the State ought to be able to waive it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, it's always a technicality.  What you're saying is, the only time that the State can do that is when the answer to the statute of limitations is unclear.  And I'm saying sometimes the State may say, "The answer is clear, but doggone it, this is just too picky-picky, too technical in this particular case."

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Would it -- would it always be an abuse of discretion for the District 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 Court to do this if the State wanted to reach the merits?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: There's no question of  -- put aside a sandbagging case, there's no question of sandbagging, and that the -- the State just wants to litigate on the merits rather than on the statute of limitations.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: In other words, can they have it -- would it be an abuse of discretion in 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 an express waiver case as opposed to a forfeiture case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought in Granberry the Court gave the Court of Appeals that discretion, since it hadn't -- the point had been missed in the District Court, been missed by everybody, until the Court of Appeals.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You acknowledge at least this much, or am I incorrect?  And it's important for me to know that.  You acknowledge at least this much, that if we read this opinion, as you do not, to be saying that the court "must" do this so that the court was not really considering all factors in the exercise of its discretion, we would have to remand. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But why would --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- why would you deal with that hypothetical when the Eleventh Circuit, in all fairness, said, "We join the Second, Fourth, Fifth, and Ninth Circuit, and rule that, even though the statute of limitations is an affirmative defense, the District Court may review the timeliness of the 2254."  That's what -- the question that the court thought it was deciding.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Why doesn't your position on the underlying merits of the timeliness question create an incentive for every habeas petitioner to file a cert petition? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, you --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- you only get the extra 90 days if you actually file, under your explanation for why this cert petition is -- why this habeas petition is untimely.  In other words, if this individual had filed a cert petition with us, his petition -- his habeas petition would be timely.  And he's only going to get the extra period, as I understand your position on the timeliness, if he files a cert petition.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Even if they file a cert petition.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So, doesn't that put them in the position of sometimes having to file that -- the habeas petition while the cert petition is still pending, if they file one?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Is there a conflict on the Circuits on that point?  I don't know. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. Mr. Hallward-Driemeier, we'll hear now from you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why, though, would we have a special rule in this respect for habeas cases?  Same question I've had throughout.  Treat it like any other civil case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right, if it's not a special rule, then the answer to this is, just say, "No, you don't have to raise it sua sponte.  Moreover, 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 you cannot raise it sua sponte, except in exceptional circumstances," cite the three cases that said that. And, as far as you're suggesting it to people, you could do it just as much as you do in any other civil case, no special rule.  If they want to move to amend, fine, end of case, we did it in a paragraph.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, the same with strike suits.  You know, there are a lot of class-action strike suits and so forth that at least one group of people think are terrible and the other group think are great.  So, you say, "Well, we're going to have a special thing here for amendments in strike suits. Have a special amendment for some" -- you know, why proliferate law?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Not generally.  Statute of limitations, like res judicata, they are 8(c) affirmative defenses, and preclusion doctrine is for the party to waive or not, just like the statute of limitations.  I don't think there's any rule that says a judge in the run-of-the-mine case acts properly by interjecting preclusion into a case where no party has raised it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me.  From what you just said, I take it that means that even when the State is unwilling to change its mind and says, "No, we would still prefer not to assert the defense," you would allow the court to impose it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The answer --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- is yes.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But with respect to some --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- of those, of course, AEDPA specifically promulgates new rules about when they're waived, and not.  And they -- Congress 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 hasn't done that with respect to the statute of limitations.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But, of course, "may" is -- "may" is embraced within "must."  If you "must," you "may." [Laughter.]

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. Mr. Busby, you have 4 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. The case is submitted. [Whereupon, at 11:58 a.m., the case in the above-entitled matter was submitted.] 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400
